item.title: BAT to Sell $1.36 Billion Stake in Indian Tobacco Firm ITC
item.description: British American Tobacco Plc plans to sell a stake in Indian tobacco manufacturer ITC Ltd. worth at least $1.36 billion.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: British American Tobacco Plc logos sits on a glass pane at their research and development laboratories in Southampton, U.K., on Wednesday, Jan. 18, 2017. BAT, the maker of Lucky Strike and Pall Mall cigarettes, forecast earnings growth this year as it completes its purchase of Reynolds American Inc. and expands sales of a smoking alternative product across Japan to catch up with Philip Morris International Inc. Photographer: Luke MacGregor/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Moves To End All Federal Contracts With Harvard
item.description: The Trump administration is moving to cancel all remaining federal contracts with Harvard University, worth an estimated $100 million, as part of its battle against the university. The administration has already frozen funding and blocked Harvard's ability to enroll international students, citing concerns over antisemitism and diversity efforts, and is pressuring the university to make broad policy changes. Harvard has sued the US government over the funding cuts and international student ban, and has won a temporary court order blocking the ban, with a court hearing scheduled to extend the restraining order. Janet Lorin reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Blackstone Buys $5 Billion in Private Equity Stakes From New York Pensions
item.description: Blackstone Inc. agreed to buy $5 billion of private equity holdings from the New York City pension system, one of the largest sales of its kind.
item.dc:creator: Marion Halftermeyer, Martin Z Braun

media:content.media:description: The Blackstone headquarters in New York.

item.title: BBVA’s Sabadell Bid Delayed Further as Government Starts Review
item.description: Spain’s government decided to conduct its own review of BBVA SA’s bid for rival Banco Sabadell SA, after the country’s antitrust watchdog last month cleared the offer with some conditions.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Zuloaga

media:content.media:description: A BBVA bank branch in Valencia, Spain.

item.title: Colombia’s Gas Reserves Shrink as Imports Grow
item.description: Colombia’s natural gas reserves fell to the lowest since at least 2007, putting pressure on the Andean nation to add new findings and increase imports to address a growing shortage.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Jaramillo

item.title: Gold Extends Losses as Dollar Pushes Higher on Trade Talks
item.description: Gold extended declines as the dollar swung to a gain and demand for haven assets cooled, with investors also weighing prospects for improving trade relations between the US and the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Jack Ryan

item.title: Guinea Takes Endeavour Gold Permits in Latest Round of Removals
item.description: Guinea has revoked four gold exploration permits from Endeavour Mining Plc as it continues to reclaim inactive and non-compliant mining rights.
item.dc:creator: Ougna Camara

media:content.media:description: A bowl of gold, purchased by a gold trader from local miners and millers, in Atbara, Sudan, on Thursday, Oct. 14, 2021. Mining ore in the sweltering heat of the Nubian desert is the first stage of an illicit network that has exploded in the past 18 months following a pandemic-induced spike in the gold price. Photographer: Simon Marks/Bloomberg

item.title: Bond Bull Steven Major Ousted as HSBC Slashes Jobs
item.description: HSBC is dismissing over two dozen analysts as part of a new restructuring, That includes the bank's global head of fixed income research Steven Major. The changes are part of the CEO's efforts to increase efficiency. Bloomberg Finance Reporter William Shaw joined Wall Street Beat on Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the changes. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: From Your Fridge to the Pharmacy, how Tariffs Could Disrupt It All
item.description: Aptar is a US-based global manufacturer of consumer dispensing packaging and drug delivery devices with manufacturing operations in 18 countries. The company makes packaging for everyday products like Kraft-Heinz Ketchup and Lysol air fresheners. Stephan Tanda, Aptar Group President & CEO joined the C-Suite on Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about how he's positioning his company as tariff tensions ebb and flow. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Fund Managers Put on Notice by $65 Billion Dutch Investor
item.description: Dutch pension fund PME is issuing a blanket warning to US money managers, amid concerns America’s investment industry is caving in to pressure from the Trump administration to abandon basic principles of stewardship.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: President Trump signs executive orders during a ceremony in the Oval Office following the inauguration of his second term.

item.title: Mexico Stocks Hit Record as Tariff Respite Boosts Risky Assets
item.description: Mexican stocks surged to an all-time high on Tuesday, buoyed by a post-Liberation Day bounce and tracking a broader rally in Latin American equities.
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Butler, Vinicius Andrade

media:content.media:description: The Mexican stock exchange in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. The Mexican peso slumped after US President Donald Trump imposed new import tariffs against the country, though other developing-nation currencies held their own amid concerns about the impact of the escalating trade war on growth in the world’s largest economy.

item.title: US Stocks Gain on Easing Tension With EU, Consumer Confidence
item.description: US stocks gained after a long holiday weekend on signs of cooling trade tensions between the US and the European Union, rebounding consumer confidence and falling bond yields.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Neinor in Talks to Buy Stake in Rival Spain Developer Aedas
item.description: Neinor Homes SA is in talks to acquire a significant stake in rival Aedas Homes SA, a potential deal that could create Spain’s biggest developer with a combined market value of about $2.6 billion.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Zuloaga, Rodrigo Orihuela

item.title: Rio Tinto Copper Mine Boosted as Supreme Court Rejects Apaches’ Appeal
item.description: The US Supreme Court cleared a major obstacle to Rio Tinto Plc’s construction of North America’s largest copper mine, rejecting an appeal by a Native American group that said the Arizona project will destroy a sacred area.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The Apache Leap Mountain in Superior, Arizona, in 2023. Photographer: Matt York/AP Photo

item.title: Stocks Jump on Consumer Confidence, Trade Talks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street kicked off the week with big gains in stocks on renewed optimism about the economic trajectory after US consumer confidence rebounded and the US and the European Union sped up trade negotiations. A global rally in bonds also helped sentiment on signs that Japan will be ready to calm jittery debt markets.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Treasury Cuts Size of Bill Sales as Debt-Cap Pressures Bite
item.description: The US Treasury Department cut the size of its four- and eight-week bill auctions, the beginning of what’s likely to be a series of reductions as the government seeks to preserve its borrowing authority under the statutory debt ceiling.
item.dc:creator: Alex Harris

media:content.media:description: A flag with the seal of the Treasury Department in Washington, DC.

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 5/27/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stablecoin Issuer Circle, Holders Seek $624 Million in IPO
item.description: Circle Internet Group Inc. and some of its backers are seeking to raise as much as $624 million in a long-awaited initial public offering, as crypto companies increasingly tap the public markets to raise funds.
item.dc:creator: Monique Mulima, David Morris

item.title: DoorDash Seeks $2 Billion in Convertible Bond After Deal Spree
item.description: DoorDash Inc. is raising $2 billion from the sale of convertible bonds, less than a month after the US’ largest food-delivery service announced a pair of sizable deals to expand its global footprint.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes, Yiqin Shen

media:content.media:description: A delivery worker carries a DoorDash bag in New York, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. In a matter of five hours, the US delivery firm DoorDash Inc. announced two multibillion-dollar acquisitions that stand to turn what is already the largest food-delivery service in the US into a formidable global player.

item.title: Buyout on Hold: Seven & i Investors Eye Execution Before Backing Deal or Strategy
item.description: Seven & i Holdings Co. shareholders approved a new board at a low-key annual meeting, despite the drama surrounding a company facing a takeover proposal by Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc., the operator of Circle K stores.
item.dc:creator: Kanoko Matsuyama, Koh Yoshida

item.title: Wall Street Can’t Beat Michael Saylor’s Runaway Crypto Engine
item.description: Wall Street keeps inventing new ways to ride the digital-currency boom — from amped-up ETFs and tokenized funds to structured products — and crypto competitors keep circling. But the trade still delivering the biggest rewards belongs to Michael Saylor.
item.dc:creator: Vildana Hajric

media:content.media:description: Michael Saylor Photographer: Jason C. Andrew/Bloomberg

item.title: Newly Minted ETFs Buck Vanguard Effect as Fees Hit Record High
item.description: Jack Bogle may have envisioned a world of rock-bottom fees and sleepy index funds — but the ETF market in 2025 looks more like a speculative arcade than a cost-cutting utopia.
item.dc:creator: Emily Graffeo

item.title: Canadian Aluminum Trader Blames Its Bankruptcy on Trade War
item.description: A Canadian aluminum trader that had been struggling to restructure its debt has filed bankruptcy in the US and Canada, saying the American trade war helped push the company over the edge.
item.dc:creator: Steven Church

media:content.media:description: Cut aluminium signs at a manufacturing facility in Langford, British Columbia.

item.title: Oil Declines as OPEC+ Supply Meeting Overshadows EU Trade Thaw
item.description: Oil slipped as the looming prospect of another major OPEC+ production increase overshadowed easing trade tensions between the European Union and the US.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: A tank at the Burnaby Terminal in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, on Saturday, Feb. 24, 2024. With an expansion of the Trans Mountain crude pipeline set to start operation in the months ahead, the supply of western Canadian oil available for export is set to rise by about 500,000 barrels a day by the end of next year, S&P Global estimates. Photographer: Paige Taylor White/Bloomberg

item.title: Agnico Eagle’s Ascent to Most Valuable Gold Stock Lifts Paulson
item.description: When billionaire hedge fund manager John Paulson’s firm made a big bet on gold after the 2008 financial crisis, his fund picked several small- and mid-size gold miners. One of those is now vying to be the world’s most valuable bullion stock.
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey Morgan

media:content.media:description: Billionaire John Paulson, president and founder of Paulson & Co., during a Bloomberg Television interview at his home on Long Island, New York, on Thursday, Aug. 12, 2021. Paulson talked about the trade that made him a billionaire, gold, cryptocurrencies and inflation.

item.title: Worldpay Teams Up With BVNK to Offer USDC Stablecoin Payouts
item.description: Payments processing firm Worldpay will allow customers in the US and Europe to make disbursements with Circle Internet Financial’s USDC stablecoin.
item.dc:creator: Emily Mason

item.title: Fed's Barkin Says Data Show US on Same Trajectory as Last Year
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Tom Barkin says the recent economic data show the US is on the same trajectory as the last year or two on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Media to Raise $2.5 Billion in Capital to Buy Bitcoin
item.description: Trump Media & Technology Group Corp., the company behind Truth Social, agreed to sell around $1.5 billion in stock and $1 billion in convertible bonds to buy Bitcoin for its treasury.
item.dc:creator: Monique Mulima

item.title: Salesforce Agrees to Buy Informatica in $8 Billion Deal
item.description: Salesforce Inc. will acquire Informatica Inc. for about $8 billion, with Informatica shareholders set to receive $25 in cash per share. Salesforce said it expects the deal to close early in its fiscal year 2027. Liana Baker reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Fed's Barkin on Path for Economy Amid Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Tom Barkin discusses the outlook for the US economy and current business and consumer sentiment with Matt Miller, Katie Greifeld and Mike McKee on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)
